item.description:
Zhang Qi is an abstract strategy game, in which the players simply take turns claiming a number from the set {2, 5, 7, 10, 11, 14, 15, 17, 20, 23, 25, 31, 33, 37, 39, 40, 44, 46, 49, 50, 53, 59, 60, 61, 62, 68, 71, 73, 74, 78, 79, 83}. What makes the game something other than a trivial exercise is that the person whose turn it is, is always the player with the lower score, which means that getting too far ahead can ultimately set you behind, as your opponent takes several turns in a row. The winner is the player whose claimed numbers have the highest sum.

Because the shape of the board is irrelevant (technically, you could play by grabbing numbered chips from the middle of the table), the designer gave the game some visual appeal by making the board square, with numbered spaces set up like the board was broken into fragments.

Tequila Pigs, The classic Bar Game. Throw Pigs, Best Score Wins.

 Pass the Pigs

A Warpspawn card game. Players draw cards to acquire the foodstuffs necessary to cook "a meal fit for a king"; or else a commoner, as his majesty doesn't eat gruel and the hoi polli don't get to eat pomegranate. Each of the more than 100 foods falls into a category, such as fish or drink or bread. Each of the 20 recipes requires an appropriate number of foods from a category or several categories. Each recipe has a number of points which a player earns upon discarding the requisite food cards. First to get 100 points wins.

Traditionally a gambling game, also known as Tripps.

It is played with five dice.

Play:

Each player antes.

Taking turns they throw the 5 dice (or remaining dice).

The object of the game is to score the lowest amount by adding up the values of all five dice but counting 3s as zeroes.

- Each player rolls all five dice.
- Then they set aside the dice the player wishes to keep. 
- A player can keep as many as he wants, but must keep at least one die in each roll. 
- Once a dice is set aside it may not be rolled again.

The best possible score 0 by rolling all threes, however, if a player rolls all 6;s, it is called 'Shooting the Moon' and they instantly win.

After each person has rolled, the lowest score wins the pot. If there is a tie, then all yied players ante an additional amount and play again.

The winner rolls first in the next game..

item.description:
A card and dice game for 2-4 players where players roll the dice trying to match the numbered cards in front of them. The ten cards are numbered 2 through 6, and 8 through 12 (no number 7). The players also receive 25 counters in a single color. 
The game is played by rolling the dice and matching the number rolled to the cards in front of them. If a number that was previously rolled is rolled again, the next player shouts "Whoopee!" and play passes to the next player to the left who still has that number face up. If no one has that number still face up, the current player keeps rolling. If a 7 is rolled, the player has to place a counter in the center of the table and play passes to the player on the left. Play continues until one player has turned over all their cards. That player gets all the counters in the table's center plus one counter from each player per card remaining face up. That player then begins the next round.
(from the enclosed "Directions for Playing Whoopee!")

"Little ones will love rolling the blocks and matching up teddy's colorful accessories with this introductory matching game..."

This educational dexterity game helps develop visual discrimination, language skills, and fine motor skills.

Players select three bear tokens at random. Each player takes turns rolling the "bear blocks" which are actually huge 1" x 1" dice. The object of the game is to match the clothing worn by your bears with the bears on the dice.

Several play alternatives are presented in the rules. This offers some variety for the children.

Can pigs fly? Do gorillas have tails? Discover the answers to these and other fascinating animal facts in this fast playing game. Reveal an animal tile and quickly place your chips on the features you think belong to that creature. THe more features you get correct, the more points you score. But watch out - some creatures have features that will surprise you! The player with the most points wins.

(((Work on this title will start again in 2016)))

Loosely based on stock trading, company ownership and economic stability.

Each player will start the game with a small fund and during the first round will vie for low priced stock to gain control of one or more of the companies in the game. The players will then get turns to make decision of how to grow the companies they control while adding to their personal account, company account and making sure the global economy does not go bankrupt.

The player can buy upgrades in a number of different fields to grow the company profits each round. This in turn will move the stock price higher for that company. If you are invested into a company you don't own and you feel the current owner is not doing enough for the company you can try and make the deals needed to buy out controlling stock in the company or you can dump your stock and send the price falling down.

The game will comprise of only about 20% random mechanic. Just as in real life, the best laid plans can cur-come to unexpected events. On the players turn they must roll to see how many actions are allowed for their current turn...however if you need more actions, you may buy them.

The winner is the player with the most money in the personal account at games end. While you will most likely be a company owner during the course of play, you do not need to be an owner of a company at any point to win...just make the right investments.

Buy Low / Sell High
Invest and Win

The game will incorporate player to player interaction and company to company interaction...a company can also own stock in other companies. It would not be unheard of for one company by game end to have controlling stock holdings over ALL the other companies.

Unique game-board will allow players to write onto it with vis-vis type markers, to track market progress

name.value: Pieces of Eight: Rules of Pirates of the 17th and 18th Centuries

item.description:
From Publisher:

These rules have got a lot in them. They take the form of a "campaign in an evening". The land raids are fought in 15mm on a 3 x 2 foot board. Quick and fun with prisoners, looting, alarms, getting lost etc...
The sea fights are fought using 1/450th scale ships (men are 4mm high).

LIFELINE is the challenging and educational game about Life Insurance. In this game each player plays the role of head of family (father) and the goal of the game is to obtain insurance coverage in relationship to his income and responsibilities. The player who obtains these goals first is declared the winner. LIFELINE may be enjoyed by two to four players.

-- from the back of the game box (which also contains the complete rules for the game)

This appears to have been a promotional game used by the John Hancock insurance company.

Quoting the rules, again:

"Once a player has acquired a house, a wife, and 2 children, and has purchased all necessary insurance, he continues to move around the board until he reaches the Finish space, and then he is declared the winner."

Never have I heard a more ominous formula for victory as, presumably, at that point our poor victor has collected on his life insurance.

Every region in Germany has its own traditions and conventions when it comes to drinking their national beverage. Well, Franconia is no different. But this region is really special. You'll have plenty of chance to sample the outstanding local beer at more than 270 traditional Franconian private breweries. Nowhere else you'll find such a mass and variety of beer in Germany (or the world).

Landbierparadies is a specialized trade running five traditional Franconian pubs in the cities Nuremberg (host of the world's biggest toy fair) and Fürth selling only pure Franconian beverages and food.

Development of the card game started at the Essen fair 2009 and playtesting were done at most of their venues to catch the atmosphere. The 2 player card game inevitable themes to floor the typical wooden barrels of beer served at the pubs. Players distributes blond or dark beer cards to the barrels and try to meet the appropriate barrel number to drink it up and collect all the barrel matching (blonde or dark) mugs as a score. The famous "Schnapsrunde" might let you forget which color the barrel has and mix up your plans.

Cards produced by "Nürnberger Spielkarten Verlag"

item.description:

You must win your Savage Cycles to chase Master Org who has kidnapped Princess Shayla, disable the "Nexus Force Field", break Zen-Aku's curse and finally capture the evil villain Master Org. Teh first player to blast through these challenges Saves the Planet and wind the game!

(from the box back)

Dice are rolled to attempt the challenges, players can stop at any point and 'Bank' their success so far in a push-your-luck system.

item.description:
In this crazy competition each player tries to be the first to catch hen with his fox.
A player rolls, one by one, the four fox dice. After each throw he has to decide if he wants to move his own fox or the fox of another player as many squares as dots on the dice. But beware! Each fox can only be moved once during one's turn. Therefore you have to think twice about which fox you are going to move or if it is risky to wait in the hope of a higher score, to move your own fox. The game ends as soon as a fox catches up to the hen, thus winning the game. It also ends if a fox is too slow and is caught by the hen. In this case all the players lose and the hen crackles with triumph.

In the late-19th-century, noted London printer C.W. Faulkner published a small card game titled Domestic Economy. Needless to say, the title did not refer to Britain's gross national product or budget deficit, but to the subject that today goes by the name of Family and Consumer Science - the successful running of a household.

Displayed at the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery, Birmingham, UK, 2009-?

Part of the "Dainty Series."

item.description:

Each round brings new surprises as the values of cards change and the wacky Mischief cards come into play. Only the player with the highest score for a round (and perhaps the player who lent him a helping hand) will win points!

"A King's Life": Intriguingly the designer reports that originally the game had a very different theme, being called "A King's Life" and concerned with a royal court and its attempts to cheer up a bored king. The retheme was recommended by the publisher.

Tactico is a football game where you move around a board, where the spaces allow you to buy players, collect income from opponents where you own a majority of cards in a particular position. and challenge others to a match. The matches utilise a special dice and the team with the better players in the positions rolled on the dice are likely to win the match. Wins gain 3 points and draws 1 point. You win the game by either being the first player to amass 10 points through playing matches or by bankrupting the other players.

From the official website

Tactico recreates all the action, excitement, ups and downs of a football championship without complex rules. Go head-to-head with a single opponent or challenge the entire family.

It can be played by hardened fanatics or casual fans on an equal footing. The rules can be learned in a matter of minutes and anyone aged 6-80 could be lifting the champions cup with the right decisions and a lucky roll of the unique football shaped die.Spend your clubs money wisely to build the team that gives you the best chance against the rival players.

Collect players of matching colors to make your opponents pay millions of pounds into your coffers. Or try and build a diverse team of the most skilled players that will prove a winning formula on the pitch.

The choice is yours and what tactics you employ will decide how the game unfolds.

item.description:
Meet the Snorkels, the friendly aliens from Deneb Gamma IV. One player will control the green Snorkels, and the other player will control the purple Snorkels. Each turn, you place one of your Snorkel pieces on the board. Snorkels never move once they are placed.

Each Snorkel has four breathing tubes coming out of its body. If all of its tubes get blocked by the walls at the edge of the board or by enemy Snorkels, it passes out from lack of air and gets captured by the enemy. The first player to be captured loses the game.

A common practice among Go educators, especially those who work with kids, is to begin by teaching a somewhat simpler variant of Go known as The Capture Game. Snorkels is an adaptation of The Capture Game by Mark Engelberg, who will donate his share of the proceeds to the American Go Foundation.

The Nestorgames edition includes 3 stones that are placed before the game starts, to add variety to the board.

item.description:
The Battle for Stalingrad lasted 200 days, from July 17, 1942 to February 2, 1943. Hitler himself had ordered the capture of the key Soviet city, and his armies were determined to carry out his orders. Opposing the German armies were the civilians and armed forces of Russia. In desperate house-to-house fighting the two sides fought, bleed, and froze in the chilling Russian winter.

The Battle For Stalingrad puts you in the rubble-strewn streets as the German forces fight through one block of the city after another. The only hope for both sides is to secure the city before they run out of blood and food.

As the game unfolds, you'll see one section of the city after another ground into rubble by your ceaseless fighting. As the city deteriorates, the amount of supplies generated for your men decreases. Supplies are the lifeblood of your army. Without them, you cannot move or attack, and you'll suffer higher casualties in combat.

In the end, you'll be scrambling through the ruins, as much in search of food as the enemy.

item.description:
Colorswap is based on a juggling notation called siteswap.

Goal: Get all of your pieces including the cube into different columns and onto different colors. The cube must be played in the far right column (I)

Setup: Each player has a board and 8 pieces. There is also 1 cube sitting between all of the players. On your turn place a piece on your board in any row as far left as available. All other players immediately place a piece on their own board in the same place. When all 8 pieces are played the puzzle solving begins.

Solving the Puzzle and Scoring Points: Pieces may be moved left and right, but not up or down. The very last column on the right (I) is reserved for the cube. Once a player has all of their pieces in different columns from A-H, simultaniously on different colors and are the first to grab the cube and place it onto the missing color they score a point.

Negative Points: Players who grab the cube before finishing the puzzle get a negative point. Players can also get a negative point by grabbing the cube and finding that their answer is actually not correct.

item.description:
A body was found in the picturesque mountain village. Players try to guess the murderer and the motive behind the murder as well, as completing their own tasks (see below).

During the game players "bet" on the characteristics of the murderer. In their turn, they play an action that allows them to give a suspect an alibi. Some alibis can be made invalid through other actions. Its also possible to lower or rise the chances of a suspect being the murderer. It does also contain an deduction element, because the clues that identify the murder cannot be changed. Finding out the clues that are in the game is vital. In the end one of the clues in the game will be drawn to identify the murderer.

The game also contains a take-that element: Players can hinder the player taking his turn by giving him a task that he is obliged to fulfill instead of taking his turn, or risk negative points.

In the end, players score positive points for the correct suspect, motivation and clues and negative points for the unfulfilled private tasks.

item.description:
Barbarossa is set in a fictional Second World War setting in which cute German military girls rush against Moscow to defeat the evil magician Stalin.

The game uses the in-game deck-building mechanism from Dominion – that is, each player starts with a small deck of resource cards and during the course of the game one buys cards from an open card pool to build a deck of cards to play with. Goal of the game is to conquer Moscow. If Moscow falls the player with the most victory points wins. Victory points are acquired by conquering different cities and/or strategical positions during the game. Every time you attack a city, event cards from an event deck are drawn (e.g. General "Winter"). Barbarossa uses six different kinds of cards:


 Supply Cards: These provide points to buy other cards from the open card pool. 



 Unit Cards: The use of these cards require "Operation Points" (Each turn you start with one Operation Point) and deliver the military strength to attack cities or strategic positions (or in other words gain victory point cards).



 Operation Cards: They give you a one time bonus in different forms. After use they are not just discarded but put out of play.



 Deploy Cards: They stay in the players play area and deliver bonuses in different forms every turn.



 Target Cards: The cities and strategic positions which deliver VPs, also if you conquered strategic positions it becomes easier to attack cities.



 Event Cards: If you attack the Target cards an event is drawn and stuff happens.


Like all of Arclight's deck construction games, the illustrations are provided by famous Japanese fanzine artists.

Integrates with

 El Alamein

item.description: This is a Warpspawn card game. Each player strives to have founded the most successful Hittite Empire by time the 10th King card is played. Players draw and maintain hands of Power Cards - economics, religion, diplomacy, disasters, militaries, politics - each has a value which can be used to bid on Empire cards - kings & wars - which may allow you to also acquire cities, cultures, vassals, bronze. 2 or 4 players are playing soccer for 2x 6 minutes on a 11x14 squares field.Squares are coloured light and dark green. Each player (or team) 'owns' the fields of one colour.

The player with the ball chooses the direction he wants to shoot and rolls the die. This shows how far the ball is rolling. If the balls ends on an own field, he play further on, otherwise the opponent takes over the ball.

Each player (or team) tries to score as much as possible in the 12 minutes.

name.value: 1866: Grand Tactical Rules for the Austro-Prussian War

item.description:
Miniatures rule set covering the Seven Weeks War of 1866 involving the Prussians, Austrians, Italians and minor states.

This is the third in Bruce Weigle's series of rules covering warfare in the late 19th Century. It is primarily geared to small scale figures, i.e. 5mm to 15mm.

The book contains the period rules, scenarios and considerable period information, as well as notes on Bruce's stunning terrain models.

Publisher Blurb:

1866 is development of the popular 1870 and 1859/64 rules tailored specifically for the Austro-Prussian War, including the Bohemian, German and Italian theaters.

- Designed for fast, accurate resolution of battles with minimal tables (3) and modifiers. 
- Includes three different scales for battles involving several corps per side down to regimental level engagements. 
- Streamlined turn sequence; simple, proven command and control system; straightforward combat resolution. 
- Four-sided cheat sheet included, for two different game scales. 
- Suitable for 6mm, 10mm and 15mm basing systems; 1 inch = 100m; 1 turn =30 minutes. 
- Includes 14 historical battle scenarios (8 in Bohemia, 5 in Germany and 1 in Italy), each with several historical variants. 
- Extensive historical notes, military chronology, and complete Orders of Battle for entire war. 
- Annotated bibliography of over 75 entries.

This is a football game where no knowledge is required. The goal is to collect a full squad of players in the same colour along with a manager and a stadium. This is achieved by rolling two dice and then deciding to buy a player of the colour you land on or a manager or stadium. Other spaces include Cup Match spaces, Starplayer spaces and the Chairman's space. The Cup Match let's you challenge another player to a cup match with the winner getting a win card which you need 5 of in order to win the game. The Starplayer spaces all give you something good unlike the Chairman space which can be good or bad. Once you have your 5 cup wins you can then challenge another player to the cup final in order to win the game.

From the back of the box

You're the new owner of a major football club! the race is on to rebuild your club and win the Starplayer cup in this action packed game for family and friends. You must buy a new squad of 11 international footballers, a new manager and a new stadium (a club set) with £150 million of Starplayer money! But spend it wisely... run out of money and you are out of the game. Don't worry - there are many ways you can increase your money so you can spend more on the star players of your squad.
As you race against your opponenst to collect your club set, enjoy playing Starplayer Cup matches by rolling the unique Starplayer dice... Win five matches and complete your club set to get your club to the Cup Final. Win the exciting cup final penalty shootout using the fantastic Starplayer goal die to win the Starplayer Cup and the entire game!

You don't need any knowledge of football to win starplayer.

Made in the U.K.

From the back of the box:

Pick a shape card and lay it down. Add another! Then another! Take turns adding new shapes until . . . You've made a Silly Body."

The rules give four different games that you can play with the shape cards: We Made It Together - a cooperative variant in which the players take turns laying down cards until they both think they've made a silly body; On Our Own - a competitive variant where each players takes 20 or 30 cards and makes as many silly bodies as he or she can; Use 'Em All Up - a competitive variant where each player takes 20 or 30 cards and uses them all to create one incredible silly body; and Jump and Switch where after completing one of competitive variants you switch cards with your opponent and play the game again.

The shape cards have many different shapes and colors, but are made out of very flimsy cardboard.

name.value: The Dream to End All Dreams: World Cup Soccer

item.description:
Solitaire Statistical Replay game on World Football, it permits to replay in less than an hour any final edition of the most important soccer competition in the world, from 1930 to 2010.

Rules and flow of play are simple, but accurate.

To play match, each team simply compares his attack value versus opponent defence value. Then, each player rolls three dice to see how many goals he scores.

There are several data that have been used to rate the various teams for each edition of the World Cup, and an element of randomness has been added, to give much flavor to the replay of the tournaments.

Simply put, you compares the Attack rating of one team against the Defence rating of the opponent and viceversa, to get the number of goals scored by each team.
You may complete an entire tournament in less than an hour, but you don't have much chrome: simply the result.

A separate expansion set contains 23 different competitions taken from UEFA Eurocup (from 1980 onward), Copa America (from 1989 onward) and Africa Cup of Nations (from 2000 onward).

Another separate expansion set contains data for Champions League (from 1991 onward) and UEFA Cup/Europa League (from 2004 onward) for a total of 25 tournaments.

item.description:
It's good to be the Overlord. You have minions to grovel at your feet, limitless wealth, and absolute power over all the lands – but you know that your subjects are plotting. They envy your wealth and hope to steal it for themselves, specifically by removing you from the picture.

So you've decided to secure your power and eliminate these individuals by sending your executioner out with orders to kill the first person he meets. Unfortunately, your executioner is a gullible fellow who's extremely enthusiastic about his job – easy to dissuade and misdirect, if you're clever enough.

Who will be the first player with no excuse to miss his own funeral? Once the axe starts swinging, not even the Overlord is safe!

Kill the Overlord is a fun, fast-paced game of political murder for 4 to 8 players that can be played in about twenty minutes. The goal of the game is simple: Eliminate other players by sending the Overlord's executioner after them, while at the same time saving your own skin. Each time a player dies, his survivors climb another rung up the political ladder, taking the deceased's title and all the wealth and power that comes with it. The player who can secure enough wealth and the title of Overlord first will become the True Ultimate Supreme Overlord (and win the game).

item.description: Combat Last Man Standing is a gladiatorial style card game that pits you against your friends. The object of the game is to be the "last man standing" by attacking your opponents and causing damage to be done to each players character sheet. There are two different decks utilized in Combat LMS. The action deck provides the player with attack/defense and the respective numbers for each. The action deck is set 90 card community decks. The special deck is a 30 card deck or more that each player can construct to alter the game in many ways. Each Player has a character sheet that is used to keep track of battle damage and to distribute their statistics. The player’s statistics allow the player to further customize their warriors by giving then 12 points to distribute between the four statistics. Action, Special, Replenish, and Strength make up the four statistics. Each statistic is important in its own way. For more information about game play go to our website and read the rules section at www.councilgames.com

From the site:

Goal Pro Soccer is a dice/chart/fast action card simulation of Pro Soccer. With this game, you can replay current MLS teams or English Premier League teams or seasons from the past. Witness such greats as Pele, Franz Beckenbauer, Clint Mathis, Landon Donovan, Carlos Valderamma, Sir Stanley Matthews, Johan Cruyff, Gordon Banks, Cobi Jones, Robbie Fowler, Michael Owen, Fabien Barthez, Tim Howard as they take the field on your tabletop. Play classic matchups such as the recent World Cup Final between Germany and Brazil....can Ronaldo repeat his two goal performance or can Oliver Kahn shut out the Brazilians and take the prize back to Germany???? Or replay the whole tournament and see if longshots such as Senegal, South Korea or the US can go all the way.

All the action is here....from the shots and goals, to highlight saves, to the fouls and bookings to corner kicks and a few wild events that make "The Beautiful Game", the most popular game in the world. A game should take no more than 25 minutes once mastered and a whole tournament can be played out in a matter of a few weeks. Most of all, the game is FUN!!!

Several months of developement plus over 50 playtest matches insure that Goal Pro Soccer is one of the most accurate simulations on the market.....best of all.....the price of the game???

It's FREE......Just download the components, print it out on cardstock and you have yourself a game worth playing for hours. It is FREEWARE so if you enjoy it, pass it along to another soccer fan or sports tablegaming buddy.

User Summary:

A simple war game featuring units with varying movement, attack and range factors. Units include infantry, artillery, cavalry, support and an HQ. 
Players set up on their side of the map in any configuration desired. Combat is determined by spinning a spinner. Terrain has an impact on game play. Rivers must be crossed at bridges, towns act as defensive positions and therefore get to fire first (but only at one of the enemies that is attacking the defending unit) and most terrain features limit who can move through them.
The goal is to capture the enemy HQ or force their surrender.

The game consists of a metal frog which is put into a water basin (an empty fish tank, a bucket, whatever) and covered with water. The frog contains a hinge so the top part (the "mouth") can open. Each player receives a long straw.

The players now take turns blowing air under the frog's head. The aim is to be the last person to blow without the frog opening its mouth (thus releasing the air). When the frog opens its mouth, the last player to blow before the current player receives a point. The game is played until a certain number of points is reached by a player.
When the first player to blow makes the frog open its mouth, all other players receive a point.

The frogs were handmade as art objects by Reinhold Wittig from scrap metal (small copies with soup ladles, larger ones with drinking troughs), and there are also some unique designs.

item.description:
Six player version of Omba.

The goal is to block all opponents so eventually one is the last player to be able to make a legal move. Movement is determined by a die. A playing piece can move the number rolled, not just horizontically but also vertically. Thus getting on top of a neighboring piece and blocking it takes a roll of a two. 
A player that cannot make a legal move with his/her roll is eliminated, unless he/she still has one or more of his/her playing pieces outside the board (i.e. not used yet). In that case he/she can re-roll until a movement is possible. 
The last player who isn't completely blocked is the winner.

The playing field is star shaped. In comparison to Omba, there are a lot more possibilities for movement, so the game is more tactical and less luck driven than Omba.

This is a children's game based on the classic Stuart Little books and movies... in this case, the sequel.

Players race stand-up plastic biplane tokens along a path on the colorful game board. The children search for tiles that match the scenes on their movie "story board" displays. The first player to collect all six images from "Stuart Little 2" is the winner.

Includes the large 28" x 20" board, 4 Stuart Little tokens, 32 movie scene tiles, 4 story board displays, 6 dice, and the rules printed on an illustrated storage insert.

Players alternate turns setting the Slinky in motion (the rules call it "walking") down the slope. Where on the target card the Slinky stops tells the player how a player’s scoring peg moves on the scoreboard. (The target card is double sided for variety.) Landing on "Slunk" send a player back to Start. The first player to get to the top of the scoring chart wins.

This is a card game for 7 players. It is based around Space Pirates. Though similar to BANG!, there are several unique twists. Each player has his own unique objective, and his own unique card set based on his own unique alien race. Each player commands a ship that has 15 Hit Points. Hits are usually taken using Dice. However, while some players may have powerful attacks, the focus of the game for many players is not to destroy the other players but to accomplish an objective.

Samples:
Akzinal - A traditional thief. His goal is to capture all treasures.
Felian - A snakelike race, the Felian are tremendously territorial. Their objective is to be the last Faction standing.
Homin - This hominid race lived relatively peacefully until an alien race sent an explosive that destroyed many lives, not including the lives that were lost. The Homin Captain seeks to find and neutralize the alien menace.
Morph - As their name suggests, the Morph are a race of appearance-altering people who have developed their ships to transform as well. Always seeking to attain transcendence, the Morph try to do so by learning from other people. Their objective is to acquire technologies from all other factions.
Ralyk - Wolf Men. Because their genetics prevent their reproduction, the only way they can continue as a race is to (naturally) turn others into Wolf Men. They prominently seek out the Alphas of each species. This said, their objective is to capture all opposing Captains through duel or by kidnapping.
Var*por - A squidlike race who travel aboard live ships. These ships look like rays but hold solar powers. Thus they are called StarRay in first phase and SunRay in later phase. The objective is to raise a StarRay to its second phase and lead it to a New Birth phase where another StarRay is born.
Wallaboo - A small teleporting Kangaroo race who stow away on ships and influence the playing field. They maneuver game play while attempting to remain unnoticed and escape capture. Their objective is to be free aboard the winning ship.

Objectives that are well thought out with interesting back-story, only made more incredible by the fact that this game is so easy to play.

As stated, each faction has their own unique abilities, but a shared deck unites them all. In this shared deck are Detonator Cards (the central card which allows players to make basic attacks or to play their faction cards), Evasion Tactics which protect ships from attack, Quick Fix cards to restore Hit Points, Steal cards that allow players to steal Faction abilities from other factions (including Captains and Treasures), Void cards which return continuous abilities to their decks, and other (more unique) abilities.

Dueling, a major factor of Traditional Bang, is now done exclusively in battle for captains. (All players may Duel for opposing captains, as Captain cards hold unique abilities. This was also true of Traditional Bang). This does not require the use of cards. Any player can Duel with an opponent that has less than 1/2 Hit Points. Each Captain has his own HP rating, and a series of D6 Dice Rolls resolves a Duel. The winner retains the opponent's captain along with his unique ability.

Another new feature of Shores of Heaven is a mini game called Common Threat, wherein 2 D6's are rolled and the values are multiplied. Players must work together to destroy the Common Threat before returning to play. Each player who fails to neutralize the threat loses 1 HP. The Victor redeems all lost HP.

FOLLOWING IS A SIMPLE RULE SET. SOON, WITH PRINTABLE CARDS TO BE UPLOADED, YOU SHOULD BE ABLE TO PLAY THE GAME WITHIN A FEW MINUTES...

START 
Along with cards, you will need a D4 and a D6 to play. (Unique sided dice are usually inexpensive and can be found on the internet or at specialty board game shops.)
After Starting Position has been determined, each player pulls a faction at random from the SPECIES deck. This card remains face up until the faction is removed from play. There are two SPECIES decks, only one of which has a WALLABOO card. If the WALLABOO card is chosen, the Wallaboo faction keeps the additional SPECIES deck to mark his current position. His position is revealed to only the player who plays the IMPRISONMENT card. (Each faction has an IMPRISONMENT card in his FACTION deck.) If the Wallaboo plays his TRUCE card, his position is then revealed to all players.
At this point, all players but the Homin also receive a THREAT card, distinguishing them as a Menace or as Benign.
OBJECTIVES:
Akzínal - Acquire all treasures. This can be done using a STEAL card from the SHARED deck or a FILCH card from your personal deck. The treasure is returned to your opponent if 1) It is VOIDED. 2) It is STOLEN. 3) It is taken back using 2 DETONATOR cards. 4) You are destroyed. (It is reshuffled into the FACTION deck.)
Felian - Be the last Faction standing. Your Treasure card can help, as it allows you to regenerate after 1 round destroyed. This card stays in effect until it is stolen or voided.
Homin - Hunt and neutralize the Menace. THREAT cards distributed at the start of play determine the Menace. If the Menace is destroyed by someone else, THREAT cards are redistributed. You must destroy the Menace yourself.
Morph - Steal and hold Faction cards from each opponent. These are considered learned abilities, and may be made Lasting Effects, regardless of status, as long as your treasure is in play. (See CARD SYMBOLS for details.) Addendum: Wallaboo movement cards effect range. Sabotage card (in Wallaboo deck) counts against your HP, and is returned to the Wallaboo deck as soon as acquired.
Ralyk - Acquire all Captains. This can be done using a Steal card, or by Dueling. (See CAPTAIN DUEL for details.) If an opponent’s ship is destroyed, his captain is left out, and a Steal card can acquire the Captain for you. 
Vär·por - Raise your StarRay to New Birth phase. See SunRay gauge. (This is a narrow purple sheet marked with 15 movements and contains pictures of SunRays at all phases.)
Wallaboo - Remain free aboard the winning faction’s ship. If imprisoned (See Imprisonment cards), you cannot play any of your cards. You can, however, discard and collect cards each round until you hold the Escape card. (Since it has a cost of 2 Detonator cards, you will want those in your hand when you find it.)
CARDS You will start with 2 FACTION cards and 5 SHARED DECK cards. This is the maximum number of cards you will hold in your hand. However, both at the start and end of your turn you will be able to replenish your hand. (Thus Attack does not penalyze Defense.) You may only discard unwanted cards at the end of your turn, before replenishing your hand. 
Cards of the same type may be stacked to boost effect. I.E. Because of this, a player who has 2 FOCUS cards may be able to roll a maximum value of 8 with a D4.
CARD SYMBOLS Each card likely has 1 or both of 2 symbols. The first is LE (Lasting Effect). The card may be played down to be in permanent use. The second is #D. This indicates how many Detonator cards must be played to use the card. If the LE has a #D over it, this indicates that there is a cost to make the card a lasting effect. If the card has LE and #D on opposite cards, it may be played as a Lasting Effect but you must play as many Detonator cards for each use.
CAPTAINS’ DUEL - Each Captain Card has a number in the upper right corner. This is how many hits a captain may take before he is defeated. Each time a Duel takes place, both captains start with full HP. Both captains roll a D6. When one opponent rolls higher, the opposite loses 1 HP. This is repeated until 1 captain is lost. Captains may only back out of a Captains’ Duel if a truce is agreed upon. The winner keeps the opponent’s captain as prisoner and can use the additional Captain’s ability freely. If you lose your Captain, you can only rescue the captain using a Steal card, or a Void card. Any captain can duel with an opponent’s captain so long as the challenged opponent has less than ½ HP. 
VOID - This card usually means the opponent forfeit’s a card of his choice. However, if you play a VOID card with a DETONATOR card, you may roll a D4. Rolling a 4 or higher (using bonus cards) can give you the ability to choose which Lasting Effects are voided. This can prove a useful tool in recollecting Captains and Treasures as the VOID card returns cards to their Faction decks.
COMMON THREAT - When this card is found, it is played immediately. Roll 2 D6’s, and multiply the scores. Each player in succession uses their attack cards to destroy the common threat. If the player fails to destroy the threat, he loses 1 HP. This continues until the threat is destroyed. The Victor receives all lost HP. The player of this card may determine the initial opponent after the dice roll. (This means that some clever calculation can result in a quick HP boost for him.)
RANGE - Unless otherwise stated, all attacks have a range of 1 in either direction. Captains’ Duel is maximum range. 
TREASURES - All opponents may steal treasures to use opponents’ treasure abilities.

item.description:
C.I.A.
Cordial Investigation Agency

CASE FILE:
The Case of the Missing Birthday Cake

Exactly one hundred years ago in 1908 (John) Noel Nichols invented the delicious drink that we have all come to know and love as Vimto. To mark this very special occasion and to celebrate Vimto's 100th Birthday, a party has been planned and will be held at the Vimto Factory.

Unfortunately, the Birthday Cake has disappeared and celebrations are on hold until we have solved the mystery of the Missing Birthday Cake.

Search each of the nine rooms in the Vimto Factory to find clues and be the first to solve the mystery. Who ate the cake, in which room and with which Vimto drink?

Good luck Detective.

This is a vintage electronic game sold in the 1970s at Radio Shack stores.

Players use plastic betting chips to wager on horses displayed on a circular computer operated game board... actually a 3-D device similar to a Simon game! The race begins when a switch is activated and two sets of lights start to rotate around the board. The moving lights stop randomly. One light indicates the winning horse and the other light indicates the payoff... 2 to 1, 10 to 1, etc.

Includes the Derby device, 100 chips, a storage insert, and rules.

A Trivia game about the Allgäu - a tourist region in the southwest of Bavaria in Germany. Its a multiple-choice-game where more than one answer can be correct. The players can pick as many answers as they want and if they get all correct get 1 point per answer. One wrong answer however and you end up with zero points.

The game consists of a "magic" crystal ball, a number of plastic chips and some cards. The players put a number of chips (of each color) on the table equalling the number of players minus one. 
The crystal ball glows in different colors until it suddenly stops at one color. Each player then has to quickly put a hand on a chip in the corresponding color. The player who is slowest (i.e. doesn't get a chip) receives a card and has to perform an action stated on it. When all cards are used up, the player with least cards is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

item.description:
The game consists of L-shaped tiles which contain squares in up to three of the four colors used in the game. 
Each player receives four open tiles, an additional tile is placed openly on the table. The players now take turns adding a tile which has to be adjacent to at least one square in the same color, while different colors have to be separated by at least one square. For each matching color the player gets a scoring chip. A new tile is drawn at the end of a turn. The player with most scoring chips at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

The Situation

On December 9th, 1940, the British Western Desert Force launched their first offensive of World War Two, catching the Italian 10th Army completely off guard. Although greatly outnumbered, the British dominated by outmaneuvering the Italians with their superior armored vehicles. In the battles of Sidi Barani, Bardia, Tobruk, and Mechili, the Italian 10th Army had been soundly defeated but remained intact to defend the gates of Tripoli.

On this, the 58th day of the offensive, the remaining operational tanks of 7th British Armoured Division and a small advanced detachment of men, guns, and armored cars are attempting to block the last escape route for the Italians.

The Italians, yet unaware of the fast approaching Western Desert blocking force, will soon find themselves desperately racing against time to break through near the small village of Beda Fomm and escape into Tripolitania before it’s too late.

The time is 1200 hrs, 5 February 1941

The complete destruction of the remnants of the Italian 10th Army hangs in the balance.

				
					The Game

Beda Fomm marks the triumphant return of one of the truly classic gaming gems originally released in 1979 by Game Designers Workshop during what many consider the heyday of traditional conflict simulation gaming. This fast-playing, operational-level game of the Battle of Beda Fomm represents a classic blend of simple gaming mechanics with nail-biting action suitable for solitaire or competition play.
 Relive the drama as the British player, maneuvering your outnumbered but superior armored vehicles and supporting personnel and weapon units to cut-off and summarily destroy the retreating Italian forces. As the Italian player, you have strength in overall numbers, but your formations are brittle and are hampered by a lack of maneuverability in attempting to break through and escape complete destruction. Simple mechanics capture the flavor of desert warfare along with the unique qualities and characteristics of the opposing forces.

This Consim Press edition represents a re-mastering of the original release by introducing many enhancements while remaining true to the original game design. This all-new edition features a full size game map, newly-designed counters with additional game markers, and updated rules presentation. You’re sure to enjoy this classic Frank Chadwick game design like never before!

This Consim Press edition represents a re-mastering of the original release by introducing many enhancements while remaining true to the original game design. This all-new edition features a full size game map, newly-designed counters with additional game markers, and updated rules presentation. You’re sure to enjoy this classic Frank Chadwick game design like never before!

CONTENTS

 One 22 x 34 inch full-color map
 One 9/16 inch double-sided counter sheet (216 counters)
 One 12-page Rulebook with Historical Background
 Two 6-sided dice
 Boxed edition




GAME SCALE

 Time: 1 hour per daylight turn (6 hours per night turn)
 Map: 1 mile per hex
 Units: Battalions, Companies, Platoons, and Tank Groups (6-8 vehicles)




Complexity: Low to Moderate
Average Playing Time: 2-3 Hours
Players: 1-2
Suitable for Solitaire Play: High

CREDITS
 Game Design: Frank Chadwick
 CP Edition Development: John Kranz
 Package Art and Design: Rodger B. MacGowan and RBM Studios
 Map, Counter Art and Design: Todd Davis
 Map, Counter Art Editor: Mark Simonitch

(source: Consimpress website)

"After a lovely day at the beach the seals are taking their beach balls home happily. But Nino the cheeky dolphin isn't done playing. With one bold leap, he always shoots from the water and snags the balls away from the seals. Where he will pop out again? Only those seals who predict his clever moves can escape Nino. Whoever brings home two of their balls first is the winner! Who will find the best route to take?"

Mit einem gewagten Sprung schießt er immer wieder aus dem Wasser und stibitzt dreist die Bälle der Robben. Alle fiebern mit: Wo wird er wieder herausspringen? Nur wer seine Robben clever zieht, kann Nino entwischen. Wer als Erster zwei Bälle nach Hause gebracht hat, gewinnt das spritzige Spiel! Wer meistert den Weg am besten?"

This is a game for children, with seals going around a circular board, trying to take their metal-marble-balls back home (the destination). However, a dolphin stands poised in the center to leap out in a random direction and knock the seals' marbles away. The goal is to avoid the dolphin and get the marble-balls back to the seals' home.

Preschool dexterity game where players take turns adding different size blocks to a stack. If the players successfully add all the blocks the penguin is rescued.

Multi-match dominos. Hexes with three matching areas: a ring on red, yellow, or blue, with 1 to 3 dots of red, yellow, or blue. Make a three-way match -- ring color, dot number, and dot color -- to get a second turn, which must be at least a two-way match. First player to run out of hexes wins.

Players divide themselves in teams. Each team consists of two or more players. During each turn, one player of the team is designated the clue giver. The clue giver takes the next card from the box. There are six lists, each of a different category, of five proper names. The clue giver must give verbal clues to get the teammates to say each name on the assigned list. The team will advance its pawn one space for each correct response. The team has forty seconds, as counted by a sand timer, to get all five names. The team that first completes one circuit around the gameboard is the winner.

In Asara, you take on the role of a wealthy builder competing to bring the most prestige to your name through constructing the largest and most ornate towers in the city. The game is played over 4 rounds (years), during which you will be acquiring the pieces for your towers and assembling them.

Players are given a hand of cards with different colors. On their turn, players play a card from their hand to an action space on the board. These spaces allow players to acquire tower pieces, get money, build a portion of their towers, etc. Once a card has been played in one of the action spaces on the board, all subsequent cards played in that area have to follow the original card’s color. Turns continue around the table until all players are out of cards for that round.
 
Scoring happens at the end of each round based on the number of towers a player has and the ornamentation present on those towers. After the scoring at the end of round 4, a final scoring occurs and bonus prestige points are given to the players with the largest towers of each color, the most towers, and the largest tower overall. The player with the most prestige points is the winner.

Fast and easy to learn tactical wargame about medieval battles.

It is a card driven game, with historical leaders, cavalry charges and countercharges, infantry defending in fortified terrain, crossbow fire and bombardment, and much more. The unique combat system and a new way to visualize the battlefield makes this game a new quality in the world of the tactical wargames.

There are many scenarios in the base game, concerning battlefields of the:
- Wars of the Roses,
- Wars of Scottish Independence,
- Hundred Years' War.

The modular board and cube-based way to visualize troops on the battlefield, let players to create an infinite number of scenarios of the whole medieval era.

Thanks to the "play and learn" rulebook composition, this game can be played with equal pleasure by two experienced players, as well as by a father and son.

item.description:
When times are tough, as indeed they are just now, gather your friends and family around the table and cosy up for a few hours of traditional fun with Irish Quest. Together you can rediscover your Irish roots and the family values that really matter when you play Irish Quest. An ideal way to spend quality time together. Be Irish and proud of it!

Your Country, Your Heritage, Your Passion

Test your knowledge of everything Irish and learn so much more by playing Irish Quest. With over 2,000 Irish multiple-choice questions in four different categories HISTORY, LAND AND NATURE, CULTURE and MODERN there’s so much to share and learn, and the accompanying booklet enhances the experience with further explanations for many of the more interesting and unusual answers. But beware! As you tour the country to collect the letters ‘Q U E S T’, Destiny cards may help or hinder you and you will need to earn sovereigns to help pay your way.

From the Publisher...

The Game of Christmas Cheer is a simple, small game (box is 3.5" square) for families to play during the holidays or anytime you’d like to remember Christmas.

The object of the game is to be the one with the most Christmas cheer (chips) at the end. Cards depict holiday events like last minute shopping and package in the mail. Each one instruct the players to pass cheer right or left, take some from the center. Players can choose to keep rolling the die, hoping to get more cheer, but some rolls can make them lose it all. Everyone has fun because it’s impossible to know who will be holding the most cheer when the game ends.

It’s for 3 to 6 players. There is text to read on the cards, but as long as one player at the table can read even young children can easily enjoy the game. It takes only about 10 minutes to play.

The game comes with:
- a wooden hand-painted gingerbread man pawn (each is unique) 
- a 1" die (green or red) 
- 10 color cards 
- 60 plastic chips 
- 1 rule sheet (not in the picture)

Besides just enjoying the game with family and friends, rules are included to use it to give out gifts at a party or family get-together during the holidays.

From the rules "The object of the game is to be the first contractor to complete the job and cross the finish line. Just as in actual contracting situations, the quicker the job is completed, the better off you are."

This game was designed for marketing. One player chooses the CMI Autograder-55 and the other players choose any of the 3 generic autograders. Players take turns spinning a wheel to determine how many spaces they move. Spaces can direct the player to lose a turn, go again, draw a card, etc. Many cards tell the player to loose a turn but do not affect the player controlling the Autograder-55 and then describes why the superior technology of that machine makes it a better performer.

In this battle game, each player is trying to end up last pig standing by forcing the other players to give up the five energy disks with which each began the game. To do this, you roll a die, and your pig must travel forward around the board and land on the same space as or pass by another pig -- when this happens, that pig's player must toss one energy disk into the game box.

The main deviation from this pattern comes when a pig lands by exact count on one of the five sparkling starter spaces in the arena. When this happens, the player has three choices at the beginning of the next turn. To continue on, to reverse direction and move, or to roll the Die of Power; the Die of Power may cause you to lose your turn, reclaim an energy disk, move 5 spaces or teleport to any space, designate another player to lose a disk, or let you become the Turbo Cochon (Pig), who teleports, forces another player to lose an energy disk, and collects that disk all in one fell swoop. One by one, players are knocked out of the game until the remaining player wins.

When times are tough, as indeed they are just now, gather your friends and family around the table and cosy up for a few hours of traditional fun with Welsh Quest. Together you can rediscover your Welsh roots and the family values that really matter when you play Welsh Quest. An ideal way to spend quality time together. Be Welsh and proud of it!

Your Country, Your Heritage, Your Passion

Test your knowledge of everything Welsh and learn so much more by playing Welsh Quest. With over 2,000 Welsh multiple-choice questions in four different categories HISTORY, LAND AND NATURE, CULTURE and MODERN there’s so much to share and learn, and the accompanying booklet enhances the experience with further explanations for many of the more interesting and unusual answers. But beware! As you tour the country to collect the letters ‘Q U E S T’, Destiny cards may help or hinder you and you will need to earn sovereigns to help pay your way.

A dexterity children game in which players take turns to place as many glittering drops as possible on a flower. But they must beware -- when the drops are too heavy, they will lose balance and the flower will shake off the dew. The first player to place all of his dew drops on the flower wins the game.

The Shogun has offered your family the isle of Hokkaido for years of faithful service. But your patriarch is in failing health, and his sons must prove who is the most worthy of Hokkaido! Hokkaido is the second game in Blue Panther's "Trailblazer Series", following Nepal. Featuring quick gameplay, key decisions every turn, and just a little bit of conflict. Hokkaido is a strategy game with a Euro feel for 2-4 players that plays in an hour or less. Players take the role of a clan leader in feudal Japan, trailblazing trade routes and holding on to them in an effort to convince the Shogun that they are worthy to rule the isle of Hokkaido. Three actions per turn, seven actions to choose from including move, grow, sea move, claim public trade route, draw a card, discard, reveal private trade route. An important decision or two every turn, and never enough actions to get it all done. Conflict can be used, but sparingly, when a province is overpopulated. A simple and robust combat mechanic rewards players who plan ahead. Victory is won through control of key trade routes and area control. Population limits scale with the number of players to ensure a tight board for any number of players.

FROM THE PUBLISHER"S INTRODUCTION (EXCEPTS):

Skirmish! is a quick-to-learn, easy-to-set-up game of combat that can be played using almost any miniatures figures. The point of this game is to simulate small-scale battles and to play as well as possible and to have fun, win or not.
Skirmish! is intended for both veteran and novice players. It is simple enough to be a beginner's first wargame, and versatile and expandable enough to satisfy more experienced gamers, especially those who want to pull out some of their old toy soldiers out of a footlocker or the closet and use them in a game.

Skirmish! is designed for simplicity and playability. The basic rules can be read, a handful of soldiers selected, and a game set up in about 20 minutes, and in much less time than that for players already familiar with the rules. And, while their emphasis is on playability, these rules allow for consistency, taking the gaming action up at least a few steps from merely "playing soldiers".

Would-be hardcore gamers mau complain that these rules are not "realistic". Sure they are. They are just exceptionally streamlined, and in the spirit of "playing soldiers" are simple and flexible. There are no cumbersome charts or combat matrices, no supporting papaerwork to keep track of a game in play, and a minimum of simple tables. Most attacks can be completely resolved with a simple roll of the dice.

Anything beyond the basic rules is optional. With the incorporation of selected optional rules, Skirmish! can be made as complex as is enjoyable for the players. Most players will eventually, if not initially, want to use some of the optional rules.

From RPGnow.com:

This book is part of a thematic series of works on miniatures wargaming published by Skirmisher that includes the H.G. Wells books Little Wars and Floor Games, the company’s spinoff Little Orc Wars rules, and the Quactica miniatures rules.

Look on the back of your Koala Crisp cereal box - free game!

From the Game Rules:

In this game, you need to get through a typical day, trying to make some good, healthy choices along the way.

Look on the inside of your Panda Puffs cereal box - it's a free game!

From the Game Rules:

OBJECT: To get your animal off the "Endangered Species" list by advancing them off the board. Just like in real life, you're only going to get so far and then get sent back to square one. Hopefully, with a bit of luck and skill, you'll make your way to the top. Too bad it's not that easy for the real animals!

Main Street in your town has just been incorporated into Route 66, the US highway system that links Chicago to Los Angeles. Can you manage to snag a piece of the tourist business pie? Will you build a motel or a cafe? How about a mini-golf and can you make money from your neighbor's giant ball of twine? Some of your family may work for free, but you will have to pay a higher wage to get the people in town to leave your competition and work for you.

Erecting neon signs and billboards, expanding current businesses, and annexing land to increase the size of the town (can we actually incorporate that huge canyon over there?) are all viable ways to make the most money before the interstate system opens and all the traffic bypasses the towns.

In the Ancient Greece, the poleis (city-states) thrived increasing their population and culture, occasionally waging war against each other, erecting buildings and celebrating ceremonies to get the favour of the deities abiding on Mount Olympus. The players will lead one of these city-states (like Athens, Sparta, Corinth, Thebes, Argos and others) expanding it and worshipping the various gods in order to become the hegemonic power of the Peloponnesus!

Olympus is a deterministic (i.e., non-random) strategy game, based on worker-placement, resource management and building an efficient engine to score victory points (VPs). It also features a few more aggressive options than the average game based on the same premises (but the savvy player knows how to defend against them, if he prefers to quietly develop his own position).

Each player leads a city-state that is defined by six values representing population, culture, military and productivity of the three resources (grain, venison and fish). During your turn, you send one of your three priests to worship one of the ten deities (Zeus, Hera, Demetra, Artemis, Poseidon, Athena, Aphrodite, Ares, Hephaestus or Apollo). Each opponent can now send one of his priests to celebrate the ceremony with you. After that, the deity grants his favor to whoever has sent a worshipper: the favor is larger for the leading priest (the one of the active player) and smaller for all the others (for example, Athena boosts culture by two points for the city of leading priest and by one point for the others; of course no boost is given to those who refused to send a priest to worship her). That deity cannot be chosen again in the current turn.

Since almost all deities are specialized in a certain field, the players must choose which ones they prefer to worship sooner (also guessing which ones may be of interest for the opponents and which ones are safer to skip as they will not be chosen until later) and when it is better to get a smaller benefit following the priest of another player rather than saving a priest to get a greater boon but in a field that may not interest them as much (sort of quality over quantity).

The resources your city produces (worshipping the correct deities) can be spent (worshipping other deities) to create buildings giving a variety of effects (and VPs), thus offering a lot of different strategic approaches to the game. Victory can be achieved with a plethora of buildings but also with very few ones. There are 45 different buildings: 33 can be built by anyone (even if someone else already did), while the other 12 are unique as only one copy of each can exist (introducing another element of contention between the players). You can also wage war to steal the resources of the other cities (if they were so foolish to keep their warehouses full and their military underdeveloped, it's just what they deserve) or invoke a terrible plague to decimate their population.

All the actions (development, production, building, war, scoring, etc.) are done by worshipping the proper deity (and some gods give you a choice like "do you develop your grain productivity – thus receiving more grain the next time you will produce it – or do you produce it now even if you won't get much?", adding crucial tactical decisions to the game).

When all the priests have been used, there's a brief upkeep to check some simple conditions (e.g., players with more than five unused resources must discard those in excess) and then a new turn begins (all priests return home and all deities can be worshipped again).

Being the first to reach the maximum value in a certain field (e.g. culture 10) gives you an award worth two VPs. When four of these awards are claimed, the game ends. Each player receives bonus points based on how developed his city is and the highest score wins.

item.description:
A traditional trick-taking card game. Each player receives 5 cards. Beginning on dealer's left, each player has one chance to bid for the number of tricks they think they can win, or passes. The winner indicates trumps with the first card led, with standard trick-taking rules thereafter.

Scoring is 1 pt per trick bid, but a bid of all 5 tricks will be one of (in order):
- Nap (gain 10 points for a win / lose 5 points if you fail)
- Wellington (10 / 10)
- Blucher (10 / 20)

Rolls Race - The exciting new game of chance.

Rolls Race is a board/dice/card game Which is played in two parts. In part I, dice rolls determine which numbers will be eliminated from the "race". It is these eliminated numbers which determine the "point values" which will be paid into the "pot". Part II consists of the actual "race" to the top of the board. Players holding cards matching the first number to reach "home", are the winners, and entitled to split the "pot".

1) What is Sector?
Sector is a board game, for 2 to 4 players. The game is based on the strategic occupation of the game board. Taking turns, the participants role a normal cube die and place pieces on the board, according to preset rules. Some of the pieces, or some of the squares where the pieces can be placed, have specific properties that affect how that particular turn is played. Players who can't, in their turn, place the required pieces on the squares of the board are eliminated. The winner is the last surviving player.

2) What do I need to play Sector?
(a) A game board (15x15 squares), with special squares marked;
(b) 225 normal pieces and 20 special pieces (per 2 players);
(c) Nontransparent bag(s) or box(es) for the pieces;
(d) One cube (1-6) die.

3) Let's start the game. Who plays first?
Let the players throw the die and the person with the highest number goes first. After that, the turn proceeds clockwise.

4) What does each turn consist of?
(a) Roll the die.
(b) Take the number of pieces corresponding to the value obtained in that particular throw from the nontransparent bag and place the pieces, in a straight line, on the board. If you happen to draw a special piece or the last piece happens to end in a special square, certain other rules apply.

5) It's my first turn. I've rolled the die. Where should I begin?
In the first turn, all players start in any chosen square, on the edge of the board.

6) How can I place my pieces?
The pieces, always corresponding to the number obtained with the throw of the die, must be placed in a straight line. You are not allowed to turn in a different direction nor are you allowed to place one piece over another. The line, except obviously in the first turn, must always start from a preexisting piece belonging to the current player.

7) What are special squares?
Special squares are clearly marked squares on the board that have a unique propertie. When a line, in a turn, ends on a special square, the current player can place, if possible, an extra piece on any other free special square in the board. This only happens when the turn ends on a special square, not when it crosses a special square. The extra piece is only taken from the nontransparent bag when all other pieces are in place.

8) And special pieces? What are they?
Special pieces are distinctly marked pieces that allow the player to convert, if possible, adjacent opponent pieces into his own. They are mixed up with the normal pieces in the nontransparent bag and are taken, eventually, by chance, when the player is taking the number of pieces obtained by the role of the die or taking a piece for a special square as described above. Special pieces can be used at any point of the line and in any direction as chosen by the current player. The drawing in the special piece shows the allowed positions from which the opponent´s piece(s) can be converted into a player´s piece. In the drawing, on the piece, a dark circle represents the player special piece and the light circles represent the the allowed conversion positions.

Description from the author.

A free download-and-print board game released in response to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

From the game board: "Times are getting desperate at the Deepwater Horizon. The lies show no sign of running dry and the flow of bullshit appears unstoppable. Now you and a friend can play out the greatest ecological disaster in recent history and the goliath battle of BP vs. Public Opinion. Everyone knows that appearing to do something is far better (and a whole lot cheaper) than actually doing something. So, as BP, you’re going to do your best to spin your way to a healthier share price. As the public, you can bring a certain amount of pressure to bear upon the monolithic oil company - but maybe that’s exactly what sends their PR machine into overdrive? Can BP can be relied upon to do the right thing by themselves and fix the leak?"

From the rules book

In Airline: The 'Big Business' Game the goal is to run your airline in the most efficient, profitable way, enabling you to make more money than your competitor's airline. You buy, sell, and lease aircraft, plan and develop routes and detail jet aircraft in you race to the top.

This game is branded with air New Zealand - and all routes are in the pacific. The board looks like a monopoly board.

Momentum is a dynamic abstract strategy board game in which the lead swings back and forth like the steel spheres of Newton’s cradle. Grabbing the lead and holding onto it is the challenge.

The mechanics of the game simulate the game of marbles. Players take turns dropping one of their eight marbles (glass stones) onto a square 7 x 7 game board. The momentum of the dropped marble is transferred in up to eight (orthogonal and diagonal) directions through adjacent contiguous lines of marbles. The last marble at the end of each of these lines is pushed away one cell from the dropped marble. Some fall off the board and are returned to the owning players.

When a player has only one marble left in hand, he or she is required to announce the last marble. At which point, his opponent is forced to knock at least one of his other seven marbles off the board, otherwise the opponent would lose the game.

The first player to have all eight of his or her marbles on the board at the end of his or her turn wins the game.

For beginners and perpetual games the following rule applies to the standard 7 x 7 game.
 30-Rounds Rule (Optional, recommended for beginners): If a game lasts for 30 rounds (60 player turns), play stops and the outcome is determined. If either player has a majority of marbles on the board that player wins, if not, the game ends in a draw. Players can use a spare token to keep track of rounds by using the outside edge of the board. Once around is 28 steps. Two more rounds and the game ends.

item.description:
A trivia game. Players roll the two dice and move along the board. The board is devided in three stages, swimming, biking and running. When a player lands on a question mark, he/she has to answer a question. Each stage has its own category of question.
The first player who arrives at the finish wins the game.

Keser is a Dutch employment agency.

Dino, Pebbles, Bamm Bamm and Mr Slate have lost their stuff in Bedrock.
Players have to roll and move their character's to get the stuff back. Each character has lost four items. But the character's can only carry 2 items. Players have to put the items in the sheds of the other players. 
The first player with an empty shed and arrives in Bedrock, wins the game.

"Coins" is an all-new web-published game! It's easy, fun, and exciting! It only takes three people with a handful of coins each to play, there's no board and practically no time limit.
The full rules are in the forum, but here's a short summary:
Three players each choose a coin from their hand and reveal it to the others. The winner is the player who either played the middle coin or the different coin. F.ex. with 5, 2 and 1, the winner is 2; with 2, 2, and 5, the winner is 5!
It's that easy! Try it out, write your thoughts in the forum and join us on facebook: 
http://www.facebook.com/home.php#!/group.php?gid=102042533181441&ref=ts

For other fun coin-games, check out Cognes:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/68480/cognes
... and Coin Clusters:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/70359/coin-clusters
Also, for a more traditional coin game that can be played in combination with these, try Spoof:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/18137/spoof
Another classic is Penny Football:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penny_football

It´s the year 2888, players are in control of megacorporations who rule the earth. They all have the goal to colonize the galaxy and for this purpose they are building huge space ships, hiring the colonists ( with soldiers, scientists, farmers and more amongst them ) buying equipment for their ships and finally take of to fight for the stars.

Each player has 3 Spaceships throughout the game wich have to be launched one after another.
Players are bidding for equipment, fuel and colonists and when they are satisfied with the outfitting of their ships they will launch them to colonize the different planets wich are laid out at the beginning of the game by players choice.
The equipment will prevent damage to your spaceships, give them more speed or even weapons to kill Aliens or enemy colonists.
Most planets have some sort of requirement in order to be colonized.
If there are Aliens present you can kill them with soldiers or send a diplomat and share the planet with them.
You can discover rare ore and receive equipment for the next ship for free and many more.
But you always have to send enough farmers to feed your colonists, unless you have the hydroponic farm equipment of course.
Spaceships are moved by different dice ( D4, D6, D8 ) but whenever you throw a 1 your spaceship gets damaged and loses either equipment or colonists.
Players earn the most points for the majority on a planet but they also earn ( less ) points for having a minority.
After every player has unloaded his last spaceship the game ends and the winner is the player with the most points.

For every player there will be 5 randomly drawn planets ( out of 22 ) on the map, so no game will ever be the same.
There are 10 different equipments and 7 different types of colonists to choose from.
The planets can be empty, have Alien inhabitants, accidic atmosphere, rare ore or they can be fertile.

A Monopoly clone.
Players can buy or sell stocks in companies mentioned on the board.
Playes roll the dice and move along the board. When a player lands on a company owned by another player, he/she has to pay the rent.
At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins the game.

In this Icehouse game, two players are racing their trios of pyramids in opposite directions along a five-square line. Pedestrians line the path to block you or your opponeent. During your turn, you roll a die and MUST use all your movement points that turn. You can move either your own pieces or the pedestrians. The first player to get their trio home first wins. Crosswalk may not look deep, but it is surprisingly fun and replayable.

item.description: Infiltrate is a quick strategic tussle. In this Icehouse game, two players build 15-point armies, and then try to get one of their units to the enemy's home row first. On each turn, you must move two of your pyramids. Each type of unit has special abilities. Smalls can only move by pushing another pyramid ahead of them. Larges can capture smalls or other larges. Mediums are uncapturable. With many options for army building, and a user-defined setup placement, it never plays the same twice.

item.description: Quicksand is a deep brain-burning abstract for two players, played on a set of Martian Coasters. On your turn, you can either place a pyramid onto the board, or use a placed pyramid to capture other pyramids by jumping over them. After that, you MUST rotate one of the coasters, creating a volatile board that can radically swing the balance of power. The first player to capture 15 points of opposing pyramids is the winner.

item.description: Stack Control is an Icehouse game of stacking shared pieces. Each player is assigned a color, and there is at least one neutral color in play as well. On your turn, you can stack pyramids of any color, either helping score potential points for yourself or to eliminate rival pyramids. If all your pyramids leave play, you lose! Otherwise, when there are no more moves, if you have more pips worth of pyramids in towers you control, you win. Stack Control combines the shared pieces of Volcano with the scoring mechanism of IceTowers, and bears a striking similarity to Sid Sackson's Focus.

item.description:
Contents 23 dice, some with numbers all the way around, some with mathematical symbols all the way around.
3 minute Egg timer
Cup

Turn the egg timer over and roll however many dice you wish. Try to make a true mathematical equation with as many dice as possible, while rerolling whichever dice you wish. When the timer stops, score a point for each die in the true equation.

example. "10 + 6 = 11 + 5" is worth 7 points
